Scott Edelman's article "Colleges Can Take Action Against Agents" (The Times, Oct. 15) raises some important issues concerning unscrupulous agents who solicit and tender gifts to student-athletes and the effect of such conduct on their eligibility. In focusing on the remedies available under various state statutes to deter such conduct, he does not point out that already in place in the National Football League is a very effective mechanism.

Under the Collective Bargaining Agreement between the N.F.L. Players Association and the N.F.L., the N.F.L.P.A. has the power to certify all agents who represent players in individual contract negotiations with N.F.L. clubs. The N.F.L.P.A. would certainly have the power to deny certification to any agent who was found to have imperiled the eligibility of any student-athlete in the manner described in Edlelman's article.
